message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about the role of hummingbirds in pollination. Hummingbirds drink nectar from flowers and as they do so, they also collect pollen on their bodies. When they leave the flower, they carry this pollen with them and transfer it to other flowers, aiding in the process of pollination. Option (A) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not turn bright purple when they leave flowers. Option (B) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not fall to the ground when they leave flowers. Option (D) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not eat small birds.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the pollination process. When hummingbirds drink nectar from flowers, they often come into contact with the flower's reproductive structures, such as the stamen and pistil. These structures contain pollen, which is like a special dust that allows for pollination. As hummingbirds move from flower to flower, they inadvertently transfer this pollen, helping to fertilize other flowers. Option (A) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not turn bright purple when they leave a flower. Option (B) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not fall to the ground after leaving a flower. Option (D) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not eat other birds.

This question requires basic knowledge about the role of hummingbirds in pollination. Hummingbirds transfer pollen from flower to flower as they drink nectar, which helps pollinate plants. This "special dust" is pollen that sticks to their bodies and is carried to the next flower, aiding in the reproduction of flowering plants. Option (A) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not change color after leaving a flower. Option (B) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not fall to the ground after visiting a flower. Option (D) is incorrect because hummingbirds are nectar feeders and do not eat other birds.

This question requires basic knowledge about the relationship between hummingbirds and flowers. When hummingbirds drink nectar from flowers, they often brush against the flower's reproductive parts, including the stamen (which contains pollen). As they leave the flower, they carry this pollen with them and may transfer it to other flowers, aiding in the process of pollination. Option (A) is incorrect because there is no mention of hummingbirds turning bright purple. Option (B) is incorrect because there is no indication that hummingbirds fall to the ground after leaving a flower. Option (D) is incorrect because there is no evidence that hummingbirds eat small birds.

This question requires basic knowledge about the interaction between hummingbirds and flowers. When hummingbirds drink nectar from flowers, they often come into contact with the flower's reproductive parts, such as the stamens and pistils. These parts produce a fine powder-like substance called pollen. As hummingbirds move from flower to flower, they inadvertently transfer pollen from one flower to another, aiding in the process of fertilization and plant reproduction. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer as hummingbirds bring special dust (pollen) with them when they leave the flower. Option (A) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not turn bright purple. Option (B) is also incorrect because hummingbirds do not fall to the ground after leaving a flower. Option (D) is incorrect because hummingbirds primarily feed on nectar and insects, not other birds.

As they fly from flower to flower, they inadvertently transfer this pollen, which acts as a "special dust", to other flowers, aiding in the pollination process. Option (A) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not turn bright purple. Option (B) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not fall to the ground after leaving a flower. Option (D) is incorrect because hummingbirds do not eat other birds.

This question requires basic knowledge about the role of hummingbirds in pollination. When hummingbirds drink nectar from flowers, they often brush against the stamens and pistils of the flower. This contact allows them to pick up pollen, which is a fine dust-like substance. When they leave the flower and move to another, they bring this pollen with them and transfer it to the new flower.
